030329.question: Can you maybe lend a hand with this? I can sight read rhythms fine when it's just combinations of whole/half/quarter/8ths/16th notes (with rests or dots or ties or whatever)... But I get thrown off whenever triplets (or some kind of tuplet) comes in to play. I can clap out quarter note triplets or eighth note triplets over a click, but when it comes in the middle of a measure, or on an offbeat, or if there's only just one or two (instead of 3) of the triplets or if you have the triplets tied together with other notes, or a quarter note triplet paired with an eighth note triplet... all that kind of stuff just throws me off. I guess I kind of internalized the triplets in groups of 3 (three 8th note or 3 quarter note triplets in a line starting on the downbeat) and when they don't fall like that, I just can't feel the rhythm. Do you have any tips for how to count this stuff, or better yet just like how to internalize the feel of the notes to make them c ome more easy and natural? Ideally, I just want to get to the point where I can just feel it and play it naturally and don't have to be counting continuously in my head when trying to read. Just like when playing for fun, or making my own music I'm feeling the pulses of the bar, but I'm not counting all the subdivisions just letting the rhythms come naturally. I feel like I'm probably using all these tuplets a lot in my own playing and not even realizing when I'm doing it.
030329.answer: if you are familiar with the "1 & 2 & 3 & 4 &" system for counting 8th notes, or the "1e&a2e&a3e&a4e&a" system for counting 16th notes, imagine a system of "1-trip-let-2-trip-let-3-trip-let-4-trip-let" for counting triplets. this should help you subdivide. for example, the sort of west african triplet clave rhythm would be 1 _ let (2) trip-let (3) _ let (4) _ _. write out some random combinations of triplets, and practice counting like this. maybe even go to random dot org and get a string of 12 binary digits, and say the 1's are where the notes are and the 0's are where the spaces are. write it out as triplets (that will give you writing practice) and then read it (that will give you reading practice.)

030605.question: 1.29.18 2:07 pm Hey, just want to say thanks! I tried your suggestion and randomizing the hits/rests with the triplets has been super helpful. I also have this app on my phone that's like a metronome but you can plug in the specific rhythm notation, so I've been doing that to check to make sure my timing is good. Couple more questions about this whole thing. Are triplets almost always going going to be grouped in 3's? Maybe its not really common cause I'm not seeing it in any of my sheet music, but would you ever see something like one eighth note/rest triplet just by itself immediately followed by a 'regular', non-triplet note/rest? And will triplets almost always start right at the top of the beat, like would you ever see 3 quarter note triplets, but starting on the "and" of the beat? How would you count out stuff where you kind of have to subdivide a single beat into 3's as well as into 2's or 4 's for regular eighth or sixteenth notes? (sorry if this is all jumbled, I hope you understand what I mean though).
030605.answer: heads would explode, that would simply not be readable by any normal human something to that effect could happen, on a larger scale, for example you could have quarter note triplets starting on beat 2 or 4. but effectively what that would be is 8th note triplets hitting every other one. for example, take the percussion/hi-hat accents in that song 'everybody wants to rule the world' that's doing this. it would be not practical to write it as quarter note triplets, you would want to write that as 8th note triplets alternated with 8th note rests, starting with a rest, and lining up with the downbeats on 2 and 4

030946.question: You say that you almost always write lyrics and the vocal melodies together.. but what about songs like la de da or outside that have multiple verses where the vocal melody is more or less the same? (Or maybe you meant that you never really write lyrics without a vocal melody in mind). I usually write the lyrics with the melody too and they both kind of feed one another. But I always hit a wall when trying to fit lyrics to a pre-set melody (like for the 2nd/3rd verse of a song). The lyrics seem more forced and unnatural when I'm trying to fit them in a place instead of making the place around them. I'll have a good verse 1 then the other verses kind of drop off. Any tips?
030946.answer: it can be kind of a puzzle, but it should come to you in the right circumstances. do a timed run through of what you have so far, and listen very very closely when you reach the end of that run through. that is really only the authentic time when the answer should hit you, and it will feel like lightning. the more you sit there the less likely it will be to happen, and you need to take a deep breath, walk around the room, and do another run through. the answer is most likely to hit you after hearing the song properly in the right order at the right speed up until that point. pay very very close attention as you get to the end of the run through, that is when you are going to hear the answer. and when writing a second verse, don't forget that you are allowed to make adjustments to make the second time a little different

030947.question: i'm writing a song that i really really like. i have an intro, a verse, and a chorus. i am completely stumped on how to continue the song/keep the energy going after the chorus. help me billiam
030947.answer: do timed run throughs and listen very carefully to what you hear at the very end of the run through. keep an open mind, and also be open to ending the song right there if you want

031361.question: If i don't remember wrong/ you do not think music has genres. if so/ what seperates the different styles of music for you? 031361.answer: you can talk like that and it can be fun and useful, but there will never be an actual categorization system that works. try putting more than 3 songs into it and you'll break the system every time any song can have similarities and differences with any other song. even itself! i can already think of 100 different things those words mean. which makes it fun to use those words, but not reliable whatsoever for any scientific means. just for play it can be fun for entertainment purposes but no matter what system you use, it will break as soon as you add more than 2 songs. i think it's actually music's job to break these systems. if it weren't, then where's the fun, you know. i think often people who don't make music like to think these systems are somehow supposed to be reliable, which makes for an interesting game of cat and mouse which the mouse will always win

031829.question: What about the word music theory do you dislike? It seems to me like an entirely valid field of academia. 031833.question: So, how exactly did you learn so much music theory without going to any school for it? I know you don't like the term, but it seems like you know a lot about how all the notes, chords, scales and how all that sort of stuff works, yet you always say you never went to school for it. Did you read a lot of books for it? Or is there some sort of online course you could take? What would you recommend for someone like me who doesn't have the time or money to go to any music school, but desperately wants to have the know-how to make good quality music using all the tools that are available to me beyond just "sounding good"?
031833.answer: it depends what you mean by music theory maybe a few, but the learning only takes place when you are sitting there at an instrument and trying the stuff i'm sure there are zillions the only way to learn how to make good quality music is to spend as much time as possible listening, playing, trying stuff, play with others if possible, etc. If you're talking about literacy, then you just gotta learn what the names of the notes are, etc. and that part is easy. i mean, i will tell you the names of the notes, i'll tell you what anything's called, just ask. (keep in mind, many things can be called different things in different parts of the world) but if try to ask me about rules of music i can't help you. the whole reason music exists in the first place is due to rule breaking

032281.question: Is there a difference between playing in 6/8 vs playing eighth note triplets in 4/4 (or 2/4)? Like instead of counting ONE two three FOUR five six, you can count 1-trip-let, 2-trip-let?
032281.answer: it sounds the same. it just depends on whether you'd rather write the number 3 over and over again (above every group), or dot every quarter note. it's your choice. whichever you have fewer of, i'd say. 4/4 is friendlier if there is any interchange, like if there are straight 16ths in there too as well as triplets, you're fine. where as if you wrote the whole thing in 6/8 (or 12/8) and suddenly you have a straight 4 subdivision, you have to actually write like a tuplet with a ratio on top, like 4:3, which i think most people are not even familiar with. or technically you could make dotten 16th notes, which also probably no one knows how to read in that context

032330.question: Have you ever used one of those sinks where you turn the tap ever so carefully and slowly, it budges just a tiny bit and water just explodes out of the faucet, spraying everywhere and making a huge mess? Well, that's the story of my life right now. I have so many ideas and directions I want to go with music that I can't get anything done. Like, the other week I was listening to prelude to the afternoon of a faun and I was thinking how I'd love to learn orchestration and arranging and write these beautiful, epic symphonic poems. But I also LOVE prince and p funk and james brown, and I want to just devote my life to making the funkiest music ever. But I'll watch some of your videos and I love your score-writing and how you sync up music and visuals so well and how that's such a powerful tool and it makes me want to learn animation and video-making. But then I listened to some paul simon, and it's like, maybe I just want to get my acoustic guitar and ju st write some nice songs. Then I'll hear some top 40 radio and it makes me want to write really fun, upbeat, catchy bubblegum-y tunes. But my first love, the thing that made me want to be a musician was blues, and there's always a part of me that just wants to just be a blues guy... I can go on forever and write a novel about the music I want to make, and I'm being pulled in so many different directions. I'll get really motivated to do something, until I have another idea that makes me pull a 360 and want to do something entirely different. I have all these lofty goals and dreams and things I want to accomplish, but I can't stop time and do everything all at once. More than anything I want to be PROLIFIC. I want a vast library of music. But I can't commit to any one thing because nothing stands out above the rest for what direction I want to go, and what I want to devote myself too. My compass is spinning around. I'll sit at the piano or pick up my guitar to write and can't even foc us on on e thing for more than a few minutes. I'll start working on one thing, and then without even thinking, my brain switches gears and I'll be trying to do something entirely different. Every time I turn on that sink to fill my cup, the water gushes all over the place and I drop the cup and it shatters and I'm left with a spray of water everywhere, but no water in my cup to drink (or to give to others to drink). I've taken a page out of your book and have been really serious about documenting and recording every idea so nothing falls through the cracks... But I just don't know what to do next. Do you have any advice you can share with me? I'm about to explode.
032330.answer: i can tell you're going to get this, because your motivation to get it is off the charts. have you thought about picking a target location for the content

032375.question: why dont you tell anyone what software you use for stuff??? like, the 3d stuff, WHAT DO YOU USE? prolly blender, right?
032375.answer: blender was the first one that was recommended to me, and it was the first one i tried. i was very impressed with it at first, but i realized something shocking and i had to leave. and i am still puzzled by it, on an existential level, even though i don't use it. here's what happens: when you export something to video, there is no dialog box to name it, and it overwrites previous exports if the name is the same. and the name is the same by default. let me explain this again. when you export something, if you just click export, it will export it with the same name as your previous export and replace the previous export. if you want it to not do that, you have to open up a thing, then type a name, and then save. and it will not warn you if the name is the same as another. so if you export many many many different things during your process, which i do and i suspect most people do, you basically would have to remember to open that up every single time and type a new name, AND manually keep some sort of list of all the names you used and make sure you never use the same name twice. That would be like if you had a camera that saved every picture as "picture" by default, and it wiped out any previous picture named 'picture' every time you took a picture without re-naming it. so not only do you have to name your picture every time but you have to remember all the names you've ever used, so as to not risk deleting a picture. i searched and searched and i could not find an explanation for why the program is this way, or just simply how you would go about this without living in a state of mind fucktastrophy. oh and by the way there's no save dialog and it's easy to quit accidentally. so there's that too

032422.question: HALP! I HAVE A CIRCLE OF FITHTS QUIZ TOMMROW. WE ARE DOING THE FLATS.. I KNOW THE ORDER PF THE LETTERS BUT I THE PLACE,ENT OF NOTES ON THE STAFF? IS THERE ANY TRICK TO MEMORIZE IT?
032422.answer: on treble clef the middle line is B, and on bass clef the middle line is D. the letters go up with the lines and spaces. every line or space is a letter. key signatures never go off the staff, they zig zag neatly up and down. when doing the sharps there is one where it goes down a 4th twice just to stay within the boundary of the staff. just keep it on the staff, and don't put them on ledger lines

032442.question: When there is only one sharp in the key signature for treble clef, why is in on the F on the fifth line rather than the F in the first space?
032442.answer: i've never thought about that, and i don't know. but i can guess. upon closer examination i just realized that the pattern is the same whether or not it's in bass clef. if you look at the top sharp, G, right before the pattern switches, in the bass clef there seems to be no reason why it wouldn't be in the top space. so this tells me that the goal here is to not only keep them on the staff but also keep the same pattern on both clefs, for instant recognizability. i've never noticed this before but that's my best guess, after taking a closer look

032458.question: I can make up nice melodies and think about what chords would fit that and perhaps imagine it but i cant write it down on sheet music or play it on guitar/piano. Im done with minor pentatonic and major scales. I wanna include some nice harmony in that. How can i learn to do that?
032458.answer: i think it's time for you to figure out the chords for all your favorite songs (you have to do it yourself, because you can't trust anyone else to get it right, and also this won't work anyway unless you do it yourself). the more songs you learn, the more easy the whole thing will get. i think you will find that your melodies already have obvious chords attached. it's kind of like seeing the head of an animal and knowing what kind of animal the rest of the animal would be. this gets much easier once you've seen a few animals in your day

032555.question: if you've already recorded reality and notebooks quite a while ago how come you wait until a long time has passed since you wrote them to post them
032555.answer: for reality: 1. i need to search through thousands of hours to find and put together clips that are good. 2. need to make video for them 3. the more time has passed since the original recording date, the more opportunity i have to use stronger foreshadowing, and include things that are much more meaningful, and relate so much stronger to future events for notes: i didn't have this website when i made the majority of the good stuff, and it's taken a while to get up the courage to post some of the deeper crazier stuff. in the time since 2014, i've mainly just been writing things for twitter, and i do include some of that stuff on the notes page, but people tend to complain that it's too short (twitter has a length limit, so it's fine for twitter and those were written for twitter) and they make a good point. they are for twitter. so i'm not really concerned with those. generally when it comes to much longer notes, that was mostly an outlet to express creativity while i was still figuring out how to actually record full blown songs, with lyrics, with vocals, with all instruments, and with video, all entirely by myself. now that i know how to do that, that is where i spend most of my time. but there are still hundreds, perhaps thousands (depending on how you divide it) of note items which i am releasing gradually, all dated according to when it was written, as always. there are probably 10x as many notes now as there were in 2014, even if you only count the ones before 2014

032651.question: 3.8.18 8:27 pm If you divide by a number less than one, it's a multiplication (in essence). Dividing 2 by 1/2 is 4, by 1/3 is 6, etc. In other words, the smaller the fraction, the higher the multiplication. Extrapolating, you can see that dividing by zero is (abstractly) the same as multiplying by infinity. So dividing by zero doesn't give you a real answer because infinity is an abstract concept (whereas numbers are abstract concepts that can have sort-of tangible real-life equivalents). Why don't you ever use capital letters?

032726.question: the concept of dividing by 0 being 'undefined' has always made sense to me. like, on an intuitive level. today i was trying to explain it to someone who was confused by this property, and despite my best efforts, they just didn't get it. but now i'm wondering if i'm the one who misunderstood it. i'm gonna attempt to explain it to u, because i know you understand math. and maybe u can tell me if there's a flaw in my explanation/understanding. to divide a number by x, you split it into x many pieces. 8/2=4, because each of the two equal pieces of eight = four. or, 8/5=1.6, because each of the five equal pieces of eight = one and six-tenths. so, to get zero equal pieces of eight, you need to find a value that when added zero times = eight. and there isn't a value like that. do u think that makes sense (how i said it)? how could i change this explanation so it is easier to understand?
032726.answer: sure that sounds great. i've settled in on my subtraction argument, which i arrived at much earlier in the course of the questions project, and it still holds up for me

032854.question: How come almost everyone would say that a song is in the key of C# instead of the key of Db, but the key of Eb as opposed to the key of D# seems to be the norm, or F# instead of Gb etc? I know the chord name or even the note name will change depending on what key you're in. Nobody would say that Ab is the 3rd of Emajor because you go up the scale alphabetically and you don't want two A's (Ab and A natural)... Maybe I'm wrong, but it seems to me the names of key signatures themselves, are kind of set in stone for the most part Like, if I played you a song in Bb and asked you what key it was in... wouldn't you say Bb instead of A#? Or is that just me?
032854.answer: if it's major it is usually called Db, because that's less degrees in the key signature. but in a loud room, it might be better to verbally say "C#" because if you say Db they might think you said Bb right, that's because D# major spelled out properly with letters would have to be D#, E# Fx(double sharp), G#, A#, B#, and Cx(double sharp) F# and Gb are equivalent choices because they each have 6 degrees in the key signature, but it may be more often called F# for two reasons. one is kind of like the C#/Db case where F# is more verbally clear in a crowded room, but also it is more common for keys to borrow flatter notes than sharper ones. which creates no problems at all in F# where as in Gb it immediately creates double flats. actually i can think of a 3rd reason. F# as a note would be much more common than Gb because F# is the first note to go, in sharp keys. where as in flat keys Gb is is the 5th note to go. so people are already more accustomed to verbally hearing the words "F#" than Gb that's right only when the choice is obvious that's an extremely obvious case. Bb only has 2 flats where as the key of A# major would have 10 sharps. spelled out would be A#, B#, C double sharp, D#, E#, F double sharp, G double sharp

032903.question: You've seen letterman live? Is there really a sign that tells the audience when to applaud? Also, what happens after they say they have to take a commercial break? The show isn't live, so do they just keep carrying on with the interview right away?
032903.answer: i don't think so the band starts a song, they go to commercial, dave takes off his coat and paces around nervously, maybe chats a bit with bill sheft about show details, the band is playing the entire time. usually it's only about 60 seconds, and then the 5 second hand count from the director and it's back on and the band finds an end to the song wherever they are. the break can be any length, depending on if there is anything that needs to be done, but it is usually shorter than a TV commercial break, and often can be as short as 30 seconds if there's nothing that needs to be done

032921.question: for your c major shirt scale, why did you decide to put the actual content on the back on the shirt?
032921.answer: i think this is a common technique when there is a lot of readable content on a shirt. if it's on the front no one will ever be able to fully read it without the wearer patiently watching you read it. when it's on the back it is much more likely to be read, particularly by people waiting/standing in line (in a line, on line, on a line, on a queue, etc) behind the wearer. for example i think those t-shirts with tour schedules always have it on the back because it greatly increases the chances it will be read and studied by strangers, closely enough to make plans to go to the show. if the information were on the front i think it could not be studied carefully without creating a very awkward moment betweenst the viewer and the wearer

I'm having a real hard time adding parts on top because there's no defined rhythm to use as reference. 033000.answer: yes. what you might want to do is make some temporary count-offs, manually, for certain parts. many of the jingles i've done for videos aren't in time, and i often record a couple of count-off clicks in certain places. the tempo is almost arbitrary, but it helps. and plan on adjusting the hell out of everything also

033044.question: As much as I love jazz, I have never been able to "acquire" a taste for overly dissonant parts that somehow become recognied by music buffs as genius. So I wholeharedtly agree with your approach of focusing on the way music "sounds", but you seem to have an excellent grasp of theory, and this is why so many of your fans ask for tips on studying, yet you are often dismissive of such questions. I just wanted to let you know that you're a hero among aspiring musicians, and we just want to know if you have any tips on how to learn all the rules, even if it means we have to break them every now and then.
033044.answer: depending on when and where you get out of your time machine, jazz might just mean pop. or it might mean background music that is easy to listen to, and not for geniuses. it might mean a car, or even a basketball team. jazz means so many things there is almost no way to tell what someone means when they say it. sounds like what you meant is nerd music you can try to make a music theory, but the music is only going to find a new way to evade the theory. happens every time, it's the darndest thing i am not. i tell them very clearly what i think the best strategy is. i've said it hundreds of times here, over and over, and i will continue to say it until you start getting it i feel like i've spent hundreds of hours explaining this over and over again, and it feels like people never seem to quite get it. we're talking about something malleable, like hot soft clay. it can be molded into absolutely any position. maybe the reason i can never quite get people to understand this this is because it is firm enough that it will stay where it was molded, briefly, for a hot 5 seconds, but as soon as you so much as turn away or go into another room, the whole thing can and will change on you. which is by the way the biggest part of the fun

033059.question: how do regular major/minor chords such as Cm FM Gm Dm differ from C7m F7M G7m etc? so far I've made it the basics on notes and stuff but I really never grasped on chords since i have very tight schedules and unfortunately had to rest the music department in my life to do other work. actually, three questions, how do you know which notes are #/b when attempting to read music with various time signatures rather than glancing at the keyboard to know what note is which on the scale? I'd really appreciate your response
033059.answer: the 7 is supposed to go after the m, otherwise it actually looks like it means something different, because of some quirks about the way 7's are used when writing chord symbols. but the 7 means there's another note you have to have. Cm7 includes Bb note, and so on. Cmaj7 includes B note, and so on. 033072.question: What does it mean to pan audio?
033072.answer: put it to the side. if you pan it all the way to the left that means it only plays on the left speaker. if you pan it all the way to the right it means it only plays in the right speaker. if you put it in the center it means it plays equally out of both speakers. if you pan it just a little bit to the left, it plays a little bit softer on the right than on the left, so it sounds like it is coming from a little bit to the left. if you slide the pan knob left and right, it will sound like the sound is moving left and right. i hope that makes sense

033076.question: if you just say C7, the 7 is diminished, right? so its more like Cb7... In the minor scale however, Cm7 is automatically diminished because the scale goes like this so there it makes sense and you don't need the b. i might be overthinking this.
033076.answer: yes, although watch out for calling it 'diminished' because diminished usually is about b5. and 'minor' is usually about b3. when saying the 7 is lowered it's probably best to say 'flat 7' (b7) C(b7) yes. watch out, Cb7 actually looks like it means Cb(7), like B7. for example Bb7 means Bb(7) not B(b7) watch out for that, 'diminished' is associated with the 5. when you say Cm7 is diminished it sounds like you mean it has b5 but it does not right. minor or major refers to the 3, but Cmaj7 has a maj7 by association and Cmin7 has a min7 (flat 7) by association. The only weird part is when you say C7 it means major third, but flat 7. that's just what it means. (it's shorthand for C dominant 7, and the word dominant doesn't make any sense there but that's just what it's called) it's just a weird quirk of spelling, like spelling quirks in english or other languages

033100.question: 3.20.18 3:57 am "C Db, D#, E, Gb, G#, Bb". the same notes as Db melodic minor but starting on C.
033100.answer: if it were me i'd just say whole tone with the D flipped out to Db and D# instead, IF those notes you listed were the exact notes i needed. probably a lot of people would say altered but i just think there is ambiguity surrounding those situations, both in the terminology and in the reality. in places where the 'altered' scale is typically used, in your key, it would be like if you're on a C7("alt")(which could mean anything from b9 to #9 to +5) about to go to Fmin. and i think in reality your strongest notes are going to be Db, Eb, Bb, Ab, E, and then i'd say tied for the next lesser level of priority would be like F and G, and furthermore this entire umrella of chord scenarios (the C7"alt" to Fmin) in general is very friendly to dense chromatic passing tones, so the remaining notes will immediately go onto the table. this has included some of the notes not in your scale, and also i might add that i think Gb is least likely to be a good choice, actually quite frankly i don't think Gb would belong in the 'altered' scale, if we're talking about what really is strongest for most of the situations where 'alt' is written in the chord symbol. as you study a lot of tunes from the same time period, same composer, etc., you may notice them consistantly using a certain type of 'dark' V7 chord (C7 going to Fmin, in our key) and 'alt' may seem like a friendly concept within the context of one particular time period or composer, but as you travel from decade to decade you'll notice that the 'typical' scenarios become slightly different, and yet still pronounced. some calling strongly for the C7b9, or others more strongly calling for #9 and +5. just when you think you have found the archetypical type within a certain time period or sector of music, move just a few steps and you will find it's different and yet also seemingly archetypical. but i would like to repeat something i said earlier which is sure you can absolutely call your series of notes by either of the 2 previous names first mentioned in the original question, they are perfectly justified names. but be ready to clarify what notes you want if the person says 'what'

033175.question: so i was recording vocals in my living room the other day and i got all these different hums going on. went on the internet and somebody said that those are natural harmonics being produced in nature and that those happen in multiples and you gotta EQ them out. so i go to EQ the point that i think the problem is at then i see that there's also a problem with another number, which i can only surmise means that there are also problems with all the multiples of that. i could throw another EQ thing on the track and get rid of those too but i feel like at that point i'm killing the life of the track. so i talked to a dude about this and he said "the acoustics in that room are shitty, those are called standing waves, you can fix that by putting absorber pads on your wall." i knew what he was talking about cuz youtube's been targeting pad ad's to me for a while now. anyway, my question is how do YOU deal with the acoustics in whatever room you record vocal s in, if you do at all. if you feel more comfortable emailing about this i wouldn't mind. i just feel like i fucked that up, so, yeah.
033175.answer: they might not know what is going on without actually hearing your recording that might be true my room is almost entirely carpeted. that helps a lot. if you have a mostly non-carpeted room you are screwed. also there is a lot of stuff in here, which helps. there are pictures on the walls, etc. there is just a lot of stuff in here. there is actually a very small sound absorbing pad that i put on a blank spot on the wall but i think the effects are probably negligible. the sound seems to be ok but i've been noticing more lately that it's not perfect. someone actually once told me they thought i put reverb on the narration vocals on history of japan, but not the jingle vocals. this is backwards, there is no reverb on the narration, but a little bit on the jingles. what this tells me is that the natural room acoustics are audible on the narration because there is much less other music to mask it. but during the jingles, or full musical arrangements, it is not audible

033250.question: hey i asked the ska question from an hour or so ago. man i gotta talk this out, i hope you will listen because it feels important to me and i want to get your thoughts. i used to LOVE ska. streetlight manifesto was probably my first musical love. yet nobody else in my rural community seemed to like them very much. my mom called my music "mariachi music" which upset me, because her deliberate mischaracterization showed me the lack of care she had for what i liked, and that the music didn't resonate with her, so she belittled it. my dad never jived with it. nor did my siblings. my friends didn't like it at all, either, calling it too manic. so whenever i tried to share this music with anybody i liked i would get frustrated and embarrassed. i eventually stopped listening to it. years later i figured i had just grown out of it, some weird ska phase in my life in my angsty and misguided years. but recently i've been listening to a lot of ska. and i realiz ed, fuck it, i love this stuff. and everyone else is actually the weird one. this music speaks to me in ways that other music just does not really. i'm pissed that i was talked out of a love of mine. and now that i'm reclaiming this, i'm faced with the same challenge. i want to share this love but i feel so alone. how can i help people i care about feel what this music makes me feel? i gotta spread this joy or i get irritated
033250.answer: are you belittling mariachi music find people online who like the same stuff you do. youtube, reddit, many other places that's probably not a good strategy. you have a long lasting personal connection to the music, you can't just make someone have the same connection instantly. everyone is on their own unique musical journey. surely your dad, mom, siblings, all have their own music collections which they feel deeply attached to. do you think they could convince you to suddenly feel what they feel, for their music

033323.question: Hi Bill, My ex-girlfriend and I broke up (we're still good friends though). She said that I became more awkward around her in person and she didn't want to ruin our relationship. I told her that I completely understood, but in all honesty, I hate myself for fucking up what we had together. I don't know why I became so awkward around her in person, and it really irritates me that I messed up with her, because I really did love her. I just didn't want to come off as clingy and weird in public. I'm kind of a shy and quiet person most of the time, and it takes me a while to warm up to someone and show them the real me. The only reason I didn't show her the love and affection that she deserved in public is because we only really see each other in school, and I didn't want anyone looking at me strangely. I get embarrassed and nervous easily, and I would have been panicking in my head if people looked and laughed at me while I was being affectionate t owards h er. The real issue here is that I still have feelings for her. I miss what we had together. I want to try again and be less awkward around her, but I feel like she'll turn me down this time because she might find someone else or I might fuck it up again. I don't know if I'll ever find a girl like her again. I feel like a hopeless piece of shit. What do I do to make myself feel better in a time like this? (sorry for the long ass question btw) Sincerely Yours, "D" (p.s. I love your content!)

033544.question: HUGE musical breakthrough after a year of progress. tell me if i'm onto something here. so there's the feeling of home, familiarity. let's say that's a chord. now that's got certain notes in it, and is either a Major chord, which is good vibes, or Minor, which is usually a feeling of evil or sadness. But whether we're happy or sad, home is home. Now, if our next chord is what we expect it to be, using a lot of the same notes as the first chord, then that's not much of an adventure. but if all of the sudden we're playing very unexpected notes, that can have this otherworldly vibe. i discovered this by playing a D minor chord followed by a B major. because I've already played the D and the F without making it sharp or flat, you really wouldnt expect me to flip it on it's head and make both the D and the F sharp. so it feels like we've learned something new and extraordinary, especially because the B is Major compared to the unhappy minorness of home. a m i gett ing somewhere?
033544.answer: if you are suggesting that d min to b major is a drastic change, you would be right

033720.question: How can I remember how many days are in each month? I know there's that one poem '30 days hath...' .. but I can never remember the poem so that doesn't help. I know Feb is 28 (or 29), I know Oct is 31 because of halloween, and I know July is 31 because of a friend's b-day.. but other than that, no idea which ones have 30 or 31 without looking at a calendar.
033720.answer: knuckles yea that's because most of the months rhyme use the knuckles method. hold out your hands, palm down. make fists. look at the top of your knuckles. look at the knuckles and the spaces in between the knuckles. start counting the months from the left, with a month for each knuckle and space. the knuckles represent long months (31) and the spaces represent short months (30 or less). you will see they alternate until you reach the last knuckle (july), then you have to jump to your other hand and that's another knuckle (august) and keep going from there until you run out of months (december)

034069.question: You say to get better at the piano one should spend more time with it, but I'm really interested in playing chords, and naming them, is there any strategy you use when remembering how to name them?
034069.answer: i've just been familiar with them for so long i don't have a strategy. but i will teach you one to get you started, forgive me if you already know this one, and if you do i will tell you the next one. but the chord is called C major, or just "C" for short. and it is when you play the notes C, E, and G, at the same time, somewhere in the middle range of the keyboard (it doesn't count if you play all 3 notes in the bass range, that is just called mud. if there are any notes in the bass range it should be just 1 and it should be the C note.) so again this is called C major, or "C" for short. if middle C is on the bottom, that's fine. if middle C is in the middle, with G under it and E above it, that is fine (there might also be C in the bass range as well). it might be middle C on top, with G and E right under it (that is probably about as low as you might go for the C chord). it could be higher, with E330(hz) then G and C above it. all these combinations are still called C, or C major. (C as a chord automatically means C major.) I hope that is enough to get you started, forgive me if you already knew all that. if you want to know more i will tell you

034095.question: how can you identify chords by ear easier?
034095.answer: start by writing chord charts for all your favorite songs. get the chords by unpausing-pausing very quickly. it's best to work with an offline version of the file on a simple player, so that it can unpause and pause very quickly. just listen for every note you can, and identify them on your instrument. after doing this for a while and writing down chord charts for a few songs, you will become better and better aquainted for how people are using chords in music, and soon you won't have to listen to the individual notes anymore, it will be like hearing a sentence and just knowing it without thinking about the individual letters or even the words

034459.question: I'm sure people ask your for help on this all the time... but, my biggest number 1 road block to being more productive with writing more songs is hands-down lyrics. I know you say to write words together with music and I've always tried to do that, and I've even played around with that random word generator... but lyrics are like a giant fucking anchor tied to me. I can never come up with words that I'm happy with. So I have all these songs that are pretty much finished, but the vocal melody is just like humming or scat singing with some random phrases here and there thrown in. It's like the things I most want to express are the things that are hardest for me to put into words, and I've never been much for writing poetry and stories and stuff, which I know is a different ball game than lyric writing.. but still, I've never considered myself a 'writer'... writing words has just never been my strong suit creatively. I feel like if I could just get more comfort able with lyrics, then I could churn out songs like a machine. But I always second guess myself and I'm afraid I sound too cheesy or cliche or that people will laugh at me or make fun of me or whatever... Can you help?
034459.answer: if you are afraid of being cliche, then try to use words no one has ever heard before. i think you need to start having a bit more fun

034474.question: i find comfort in other people and other people's work, yet i could never find comfort in myself and my own work. ive tried to create things, but theyve always failed, like i dont feel any emotional connection with my own creations. and its weird, because i feel like i should, i should feel comfortable with myself, i should create. but my instincts are telling me to roam free- to learn, forget about it all- go consume content, find people, read stories, invest in other's worlds and creations. perhaps im rushing the whole "creation" thing. i still have lots to explore in this world, lots to learn. and i want to explore everything. i know one day itll all make sense. instead of being serious about making art, i should have fun and seek joy in all that has already been made. i feel like ive neglected the beauty the world has presented to me. i need to heal my soul by getting lost within this world. only then creation will blossom. art cannot be forc ed. creation will flow through my fingertips when it comes.

034515.question: Do you have any tips for syncing music up to dialogues and actions in videos? I'd love to be able to take video clips and give them a musical score where everything is in sync with the dialogue/action of what's going on the video (like if someone's walking downstairs I could have percussion hits that match the footsteps exactly, etc) are there any tricks to this?
034515.answer: my strategy is to make all the music myself. i understand that might not be everyone's cup of tea, because it is demanding and takes hard work, but the benefits are out of this world one good trick is to press record (with your clip synced up) and watch it and just sort of play it, after. with the right timing. so just as soon as you see the action, look away from the screen and imagine what you just saw in your head and play it synced to that, so it will be timed right, but just a bit delayed. then just go in and move it. if it's not quite right, just do it again. or if it's midi then just nudge notes to fit. fuck it, nowadays you can nudge audio notes too anyways Like how in your non-song vids youll have little musical cues and effects that sync up perfectly in time to graphics that are flashing on the screen or whatever.. Do you try thinking of the video as being at a certain bpm/time signature and using that for knowing when to come in, or is it just about watching the video a bunch of times and doing a bunch of takes until you get the timing right? Eventually, I wanna learn how to do animation and make my own videos, but I want to work on the music-side first by just setting music to clips from old movies or any other random stuff I can find.

034520.question: How can you rotate text smoothly in a video? (e.g. upright, 1deg, 2deg, etc.) The video editor I'm using appears to only let me flip, rotate right angles, and scale, and do linear transformations not involving turning.
034520.answer: you need to find another one that lets you do that, or, more likely than you think, your program might let you do it and you just haven't figured out how (maybe try holding something down while you spin it? like shift or opt or something). search online with the program name and type 'free rotate' and you should either find someone telling you how to do it or someone confirming that your program can't do it. if your program can't do it then you need to do it in another program. another insane but clever workaround, if you happen to have a graphics program (still, non-video) that does free rotate, and if you have a program to do screen recordings, you might be able to act it out in real time while recording the screen. this is an insane and strange solution but it may give you something

034695.question: How do you know when to use 2 or 9, 4 or 11, and 6 or 13 in a chord name? Sometimes it's obvious if you just have the stack of thirds (1,3,5,7,9,11,13)... but what about when the chord isn't built in numerical order like that? For example, I have this song where for an E7 I play the notes D F# G# B (all in the same octave).. would that just be called E9 even though there's no root and the F# isn't in a higher octave?
034695.answer: whichever one you are used to seeing in that situation and hopefully they won't be most of the time in that case it's called E9. at least where i'm from, it is understood to include the 7, whenever you use a number 7 or higher. where as if you had said 2, it is implied that there is no 7. E9 is a well known chord and it is well known to mean dominant 9 which means it includes 7 (D) and F#, and G#. it's all case by case. some chords have acheived written popularity under certain names

034964.question: how do you keep choruses interesting, even after many repeats?
034964.answer: run through it, from the beginning, in real time, and listen to it as if you are hearing it for the first time. be very aware at every microsecond of whether you think it's getting boring. if you feel it getting boring at a certain place, start trying to find a different way to proceed from that moment. always keep doing at-tempo run throughs to check. each microsecond is an opportunity to go in a different direction. you don't have to wait until the end or beginning of a section. time is ticking

035030.question: You keep answering questions about people thinking you're depressed (at the expense of other, more interesting questions, I'm sure). What do you expect, when self-loathing and internal restlessness are recurring themes in your music? To that, you'll say - Oh, but my lyrics aren't autobiographical! Well then, 1)How do you explain why those topics are clearly on the forefront of your mind while writing, and 2)Is there a single Reality video in which you *don't* seem frustrated and anxious? The overall emotional tone of that whole page is negative. And there's nothing wrong with that! But it explains why everyone thinks you're depressed. 035306.question: why are only certain drum sounds counted when determining tempo of a drum track? let me explain. Lets say you have a bass drum (B) and a hi hat(H). If it goes HHBHHHBHHHB and so on thats a slower tempo than if the drum track is just BBBBBBBBB. For some reason the hi hats are more seen as something between the actual tempo than the tempo itself. I dont know if im explaining it well. Hopefully you understand.
035306.answer: in general, i usually consider tempos from 60bpm to 120bpm. if it's outside that range you might double or halve it to get it within that range. but another thing usually considered is the snare, if there's a 'backbeat' you'd usually consider that 2 and 4, for example if you were at 110 bpm and your snare seems to be hitting on beat 3 only, you might re-consider the tempo to be 55, so that the snare is on 2 and 4. or if you're at 100bpm and your snare is happening on the "&" of every beat, then you might consider calling it 200 with the snare on 2 and 4. but it gets more confusing because many songs switch to half time or double time. which is where what i call the 'reasonability zone' of 60-120 comes into play. but it's more complicated still, for example in the last couple years i've been hearing a lot of songs with like a super halftime where the tempo is like 60, AND the snare is hitting on only 3. so if you went with the 2 and 4 theory then you'd be calling it 30bpm which is just not reasonable. it's just wherever you think the beat is. wherever you would tap your foot.

035391.question: i am playing a lot - improvizating songs out - and i wonder if i should continue improvizing and get better in that or stop and finish some of the songs i improvized out? like record some instruments around or do a whole new song out of it which would sound less improvizational. how do you find the isudzwiuzdb between those options? what could you recommend me please? or ask me something
035391.answer: keep your eligible song seeds in a list. chronologically by date born is usually the most helpful for me. writing is a different exercise from idea generation, and you basically just need a quiet place where you can do your work. once you're sure that you want to engage in the writing process, some important questions will be: choosing which song to work on, and how far to work on it. during 2012-2013 i had the insane idea that i was going to write just a bit on each one and move on. unfortunately this is not a strategy that will ever lead to completion (because there were hundreds of songs in there), and i worked like that for an entire year and didn't even get close to any kind of completion. (but the good news is i gained worlds of experience, and after that i felt i was a much much stronger writer). but finally i shuffled it up and organized them by percentage of completion and knocked off everything from the 70%s upwards (finishing the writing on those.) then of course you would have a whole other decision making process on which one(s) to record. Another strategy i've been using in more recent years is to make a selection from all the songs (finished or non) and stick with that and complete the writing and recording of that song. this is a good and focused strategy, but the downside is that it can be very hard to feel confident in the decision if none of the songs are beyond 20% written. i guess what i'm trying to say is there are many different strategies for choosing, but the one thing that i'm sure of which i'm trying to tell you is that the writing process is a separate process from idea generation, and you should log all your song seeds into a chronological list, and then go about making a decision on which ones to do and work on writing them. but if you haven't had too much experience in doing the actual 'writing', it might be good to just do a random selection or just go in order chronologically, just to see what goes into the whole writing thing. it's very different from improv/idea generation -- it's much more like being a doctor. you look into the original idea, you make a diagnosis, figure out what it is, where it's going, what it needs, brainstorm on what problems need to be solved, etc, and through hard thinking and trial and error, and a bit of imagination, you can find solutions. it can be grueling for the first few hours but once you have those sweet breakthroughs it can be liberating to know that you can take care of any 'song seed' and take it where it is trying to go. hopefully i've given you some information. as you can see i am still wrestling with some of this myself, mostly when it comes to the song selection strategies

035392.question: i want to finish a song but every time i listen to the idea again it already sounds different and i feel like losing the original idea - and in fact i find more fun in playing new song and more of new songs - so how do you actually finish the song when you - or your mood/ vision/ feel doesnt change that fast?
035392.answer: keep logging your ideas, but if you don't like them that much then perhaps you should keep improvising/generating new ideas until you get some that still look wild to you, even when you come back to them in the list. beware of what may happen, you will continue generating ideas and get better and better and soon you will have a list of 200 or 300 ideas which actually do drive you wild and you will realize it's impossible to complete all of them in anyone's lifetime

Anyway, in high quality audio, such as yours, when there's silence it's actually silent, there's not a little buzz in the background that comes from "sound bouncing off of other objects". 035632.question: One of the few times I have ever experienced something truly different was at a concert a few years ago, when the person organizing everything told the audience beforehand that the foreign instruments we were about to hear would sound strange to our ears, but that they were supposed to sound like that. They weren't out of tune or anything, they were simply from a context where musical beauty is something else than it is here. There is so much out there, so many instruments, so many ways to make music, that all fall outside what "we" even think of as "instruments" and "music". It feels like an insult to the world when people within a certain context points at something and calls it new or different, when it's clearly derived. It is always derived. Never new, and never different. This is why your easy-going supposedly theory-defying persona on this page is so provoking. If you had the slightest idea of the kind of superhumanly free innovation everything you say on here is actually hinting to, you wouldn't be saying it, because you never do as you say you (aspire to) do. For example, you use the word "anything" a lot, as in "do anything" -- yet you basically make music by the book, music that is always somehow firmly rooted in the schools, traditions, rules and conventions of your culture, directly or indirectly. You may think otherwise, but in that case you are wrong. Making music and videos that tend to stand out somewhat in your own narrow sliver of cultural context is no way near actually embracing a theory that says "you can do anything in music". Cut the "anything" crap. It's grandiose and pathetic. You make great music, but your ambition put into (your own) words is some unreasonable hubris shit.
035632.answer: i'm just trying to be encouraging, and share some of the mindset that helps me

035756.question: why did you put music in alto clef in "when the day goes on"? a normal person would have written that in bass clef. even I think, you would have written that in bass clef on a normal day
035756.answer: that's a good question. the reason is because i was considering the entire section (including 2 instrumental riffs.) the second half would have gone way into treble range, where as the first half was well into bass clef range. if i had used treble clef there would have been a zillion ledger lines below, and if i had used bass cleff there would have been a zillion ledger lines above. i have never used alto clef before in my life and i am generally not familiar with it, but it was just the range i needed (centered around middle C). now i know what you're thinking, the part shown doesn't go above middle C. but the second part does, although i ended up cutting it because it was distracting from the bike/grid scene. but the alto clef remains, as a tid bit for viewers like you to notice and contemplate

035849.question: Hey Bill, big fan of your songwriting :) Could you elaborate your growth as a songwriter? What do you think made the biggest difference in improving your abilities? (Or I guess equally important, did you find anything to not help at all? haha)
035849.answer: when i was much younger i wrote instrumental music only. then i wrote lyrical music. then i tried to figure out how the entire universe really works (which i actually figured out and forgot simultaneously, which i am still doing, simultaneously ever since) then i decided i wanted to get back into songwriting but my mind was melted (the universe melted it, etc) so i knew i would ultimately be stronger but also weaker at first (due to melted mind) so after a few years of helplessness, i finally decided that any starting point would have to be legitimate, so i started writing the absolute worst / weirdest stuff imaginable, on purpose, just to get started. and i discovered many magical things happening. then i recorded some of it, but i prefered to keep writing more and more and more. then i realized holy crap i'm writing much faster than i'm recording, so i recorded some more. but then i wrote much much much more. then i trained myself to write in a more structured way, rather than just starting from beginning to end crazy style. then i wrote much much more. then i combined the normal catalog with the weird catalog. then i realized holy crap i've written way way too much to ever record. so i wrote more, non-stop, for about a year and a half, this time with a cataloging system of all the existing ideas and fragments, and i was able to go through them and fix them / update them / improve them / fix them, etc. merging all the 'weird' techniques with the 'regular.' and generally got much stronger during that period, and rounded out my skills. then i decided to get them online, but then i realized, i almost forgot, videos are the trick to getting people to pay attention to the songs. so i learned how to make videos

035963.question: What does it mean when you say "I-V" or something like that in music? For instance, in the Wikipedia page fornicate 'Jazz turnarounds', I see stuff like I–VI–II–V[4] (I–V/ii–V/V–V) and V7/V–V7–I. Please explain; thank you in advance.
035963.answer: i personally don't like to use roman numerals, because it looks very confusing and it's been a long time since ancient rome. but they're just numbers, for chords. so in the key of C, for example, 1 means C major chord. 2minor means D minor chord, 3minor means E minor chord, 4 means F major chord, 5 means G major chord, 6minor means A minor chord, and 7dim means B diminshed. sometimes lower case number automatically means minor, which i guess is the advantage of the roman numbers because you can use lowercase. but i prefer to just use arabic numbers (123 etc) and just say minor if it's minor. also when i use slash marks that means a different bass note but that doesn't quite make sense for the example you gave so i'm not sure how they are using slashes. also i usually use dashes - to mean minor, but i think in your example they are just being used to separate the chords. actually there are several things about your example that don't make sense to me, but they could be using a different system

036111.question: This quote was on a music help website: "So the best way to start learning to play chords by ear isn't to dive in and start trying it with songs. It's to learn about how chord progressions work and which chords are the most frequently used - then do some dedicated ear training to recognise just those chords. This approach lets you very quickly develop a very useful ability level with this skill." Do you agree with this?
036111.answer: no. it's impossible for them to predict what music you are into. they might say 'these are the most common' but that's just from their perspective. everyone is living in a slightly different musical perspective, and has a slightly different comfort zone in terms of what music they are familiar with. i recommend learning the music you know. all music is good, and offers something to learn, and if you learn the music that made you like music, then everything is going to be fulfilling and meaningful

037649.question: Do you agree with this analysis of "hello sexy pants"? "This whole masterpiece is a analysis of late stage capitalism and its unnability to satisfy the alienated consumer it produce in the very negation of its production. What is the "pants" ? It's the commodified product par excellence, by owning the pants, you don't only own an object, you wear it and thus you make the object a part of your own identity, while you objectify yourself in the processus : at the end, the pants own you. That's how love work between humans, but that's also how it's manufactured in our spectacular society. As Baudrillard said "seduction represent mastery over the symbolic universe while power represents only mastery over the real universe" "Where'd you get those pants ?" said the cash cow : someone finally said that the king is naked. Indeed, where did those pants come from ? Isn't it the product of a bengali kid ? More deeply here relies a critiq ue of commodity fetishism : alienation make us forgot that we, as humans, are the producers of this pants; and just like the african tribes who forgot that they were the creators of their fetish, our production became our new god. No response to the quiet scream of the cow, just "hello", again and again. "I wanna know why it hurts so bad" : The ignorance of this alienation brings pain, we feel depossessed without understanding why, and when we see the pants we need to possess it badly by the act of consumption, since we don't feel that we own it by the act of production. We even have the feeling that the pants can "make a wish come true" : that's the final stage of the fetishised entity put above our heads. "Hello sexy pants did you know that I like your pants ?" : The commodity has become more than just pants. And in Congress all the boys get mad, and not because they oppose capitalism, bill wurtz is more subtile : the politicians are mad because they loose control over the system, they no longer have a word to say in the direction, just like everyone, they become simple executant of the will of the Capital. While nature is out there, represented by the squirrels, all we can see is the omnipresent modern propaganda of the media, in this TV everything looks fine and nice, there is happy faces everywhere and it tells us to be friends, but in reality it's divising humans, humans are no longer "friends", they are actors in the representation of a friendship mediated by the society of the spectacle, in wich being a friend is just a question of posture, of "friendly stance". And then the capital tell you that thanks to him you can go all around the world, and indeed it became "easy as 1, 2" to go through the hills of France : tourism - human circulation packaged for consumption, a by-product of the circulation of commodities - is the opportunity to go and see what has been banalized. The economic organization of travel to diffe rent places already guarantees their equivalence. The modernization that has reduced the time involved in traveling has simultaneously reduced the real space through which and to which one can travel. And, as Debord pointed it "while eliminating geographical distance, this society produces a new internal distance in the form of spectacular separation." After that the TV subtly reminds you the danger in criticize our society : you are against us ? Do you want to live in North Korea ? However, the nature of the commodity reaffirm itself soon after, North Korea is - like any other places and activities - something that must be subjugated to the ever expanding market, we need to shake some hands even here, for business - and pleasure - since the two must become the same unique thing But there still is hope, We all could wake up in the morning and enjoying a simple yet meaningful life. But is this true liberation ? Isn't it a way to distract us from the true solution w ich must be collective ? Isn't this a pass to being lonely and to feel "blue" ? "At the clothing store nobody tells you the whole world is changing" : everything is said, capitalism don't tell you about the world it is making, you're here to buy as a mindless robot, you don't need to understand that the world is changing, in fact you mustn't; the world is changing by itself, by the forces of the Capital; and no one truly understand how : that's the ultimate "proletarization", proletarization in its essence is the privation of knowledges for a subject and the privation of a subject for knowledges, first we lose the ability to understand what we are producing, but in consequence we now lose the ability to understand what we are consuming, it's a vicious circle, the circle of the commodity. So buy your clothes and become your products, even if the clothes is always changing, seasons by seasons, we are not even able to see it, we are trapped in the phenomena wich do n't allo w us to see the noumena, the Capital instill in us the feeling that we are living in a never ending-present wich always existed and wich will always exist "At the grocery store someone will tell you that what changed is you" : that's the response of the Capital, it's not the world that is changing, it's you, you are the one who is not in phase with the perfect and immuable "present" of the spectacular society, so stop to complain and accept your fate, submit yourself to the system, learn it's rythm or accept that you are excluded from it; and why the grocery store ? Because the control of the spectacle is in the everyday life, in the most basic consumption. The pants are already forgotten, in this insatiable run for consumption, now we have a new fetish to love : the lamp, a lamp wich is so godly that it can "light the whole darn sky", but only "at 2:pm", never forget that everything is temporal in this world, and again, the Congress could do nothing against it, it c ould not even replicate the modern worship of the commodity, the light became black down there. Simon is probably the most interesting and intriguing character of this song, he is the double bipolarity of capitalism : he is the worker wich face its own alienation, without meaning in his work he can't "remember anything he've been doing", because of the economic functionnement of capitalism, and perhaps worse, because of the ideological functionnement of capitalism he can't remember "anything he remember", "everything that was directly lived has moved away into a representation" we don't live our own life, we live the life of the Capital by the Capital for the Capital, we are just actors of a stageplay wich was written before we were born, instead of being the actor of our own artwork, we don't have our own memories since we're just travelling from one representation to another. Represented by the graphics behind him, Simon is nothing but a number among other. And the grap hics also indicate us that Simon is also the financial world, the highest abstraction of the Capital, he don't know where he come from, he don't know who he is, is just here doing what he is made to. And there is the dramatical problem : They (the worker and the trader) don't care, as long as they find out what they're - supposed - to do. The "supposed" is the key to understand it fully, supposed according to who ? To what ? To the commodity, we don't think anymore, we don't put ourselves in an historical and ontogenetic approach, we are just here, doing what the God-Capital tell us to do, we become nothing more than a cog in a machinery that depass us all, that kill every bit of liberty in us. Simon IS the system, he is the one that tell us what to do, as showed by the use of "Simon Says", Simon wants to fully become us. He want us to become him. The reward ? A sign on your checks. Also, the lamp is very sexy."

037687.question: Hi Bill, I have this really bad habit of starting really cool projects (at least, it seemed exciting stuff at the time), but then never finishing really any of them because they are displaced by new, current, in the moment things to think about and plan and try to do. It's like I forget how awesome the ideas felt to me when I came up with them. I've tried your strategy of just cateloging and recording every damn thing I think of, but I never end up going back to listen to them, and meanwhile I'm neck deepin something else that caught my attention, whether it's figuring out how the fuck math works, how the fuck computers work, how the fuck communication (e.g. talking politely, teaching) works, and also how the fuck the world works. realize of bad habits to have, this is definitely not the worst I could have. But it's just so fucking annoying when you are going to bed at 2 in the morning to wake up for school at 6:30 and you feel like you 've done nothing of substance, big and meaningful. Like I could be doing so much more, making the world just a little more cooler (I'd like to think), but just controlling the urge to swim deeper into the ocean even though you just dragged yourself out of the deep end is hard somehow. I can't shift from thinking "But what? But why?" to "time to make shit." And really? I'm realizing that I'm okay with myself still humming a long, looking at and thinking about interesting stuff, because at the end of the day it is fun. But how exactly can I keep this up forever? This is fun, but I've kind of had the same kind of fun for a while now. Can I please just switch? I'm honestly kind of just insecure, because now I'm just thinking, do I even know what I'm saying right now? Is it really that big of a deal? Even when my thoughts are trying to say otherwise. There is a disconnect here between feelings and thought, and I'm not sure what is going on. And no, those were not th e good w ords to use there...that's not quite what I meant to say... I'm not sure if it's just sleep dep. making everything wobbly and unfocused, or my brain purposely trying not to think about this. I hate the feeling when I see both people that I follow online and people around me actually doing things, nd when other people around me are like "dude just be lazy and stop caring so much" IF I CARE SO MUCH WHY AM I GOING TO BED AT 3 JUST TO FINISH A GOD DAMN SCHOOL ASSIGNMENT well, let me take that back. I didn't start until 1, but I could have finished much earlier if I would have just half-assed it which would still have gotten me an A. And I was running away from starting it because I had no idea how to do it. I'm trying to learn Debussy's L'isle Joyeuse over the summer, attempting to make a karaoke track to "and the day goes on" with a DS soundfont I have, digitizing a Bible of sorts (not religious) with cool layout, pictures, and design, making a movie with my frie nd starring King Lear, and creating computer programs to help with scheduling. (There's a circle here somewhere...) Oh, and writing college essays. The sad thing is, there is more than enough time to do all this stuff, and more time to do more, during the summer. I know this. Everything would be great if I actually worked on it, instead I'm not. And I know the answer to this is that I'm on the right track, or that there is a tipping point. It's just so frustrating, and scary, because I don't know if I want to see myself if I ever go past that tipping point. I don't want to be boxed into everything. But I'm kind of wondering if I do need some sort of box to be able to continuously work on stuff. I can't think of really a whole project to finish in a day, like your schedule when you were starting. Sorry, this kinda like turned into many different issues. I can't even lay a finger on a specific problem I'm having. Hate to bother you with this, but it's jus t a big frustration for me that I haven't changed. Well, that's not true, I have changed a little, I'm looking at *literal* trash less often... Even if you don't reply, thanks for being an outlet for my thoughts. Sorry for this huge mess of a ramble, I'm also very tired, as I'm sure you are too. -IronLotus
037687.answer: you are going through the exact same thing i went through for many years you will switch gradually, as your desire to switch continues to grow to firey new heights this is first hand proof that you are hard wired for success, beyond a shadow of a doubt. your ambitions are through the roof, and your standards are on the ceiling. and you think about it morning day and night, and in between classic i think you will find that the box is just going to be your name. you. i know it's tempting to live a thousand parallel creator's lives, but there's barely enough time to live 1. so i think an umbrella strategy might ultimately work best for you here. as soon as you get fully comfortable with the fact that you are mr. do-it-all, you can start treating yourself like a king and just plan the task sequence from there. that is why it is so vitally important to start very very short, small, and simple. there is a whole host of things that are learned AFTER you get your feet on the ground and doing things, that you never could have learned before. to sum it up into 2 points, first you will learn how far away actual real creations are from the vivid splendor you have imagined. but close on the heels of that is point 2 which is realizing how insanely much CAN be done, even just using the simplest tools available to you. learning happens fast from project to project, and the good news is, all your interests will find their way onto the menu. as long as you keep the train moving, you will surely hit all the stops and more. did i mention start small, trains are heavy

037696.question: Give me a tool to put in my songwriting tool kit please.
037696.answer: timed run throughs, with a metronome, and walk over and touch the door handle before each one. and shut the metronome off just before you get to the split point (the end of what you are sure of so far) and sit silently and try to catch the lightning bolt. it will be at its clearest within 1 second of reaching the split point. then brainstorm all the traces of things you might have learned. play 'what do we know'. then do another run through. putting ear plugs in and jogging in place while doing the run thru in your head can also be a good way to find the answers

037756.question: When it comes to learning to play an instrument, a reason why people tend to seek teachers is because there are several barriers that teachers help to break down. For example, you usually need short, easier songs to start with, so you can work your way up to the harder, more interesting songs, but simple songs (real simple, like I'm talking straight infantile) are usually more boring, thus less popular, and thus harder to find. Teachers help with this because over time they acquire tons of dead easy songs, hard songs, and the whole gradient between. Also, teachers provide a shortcut to valuable knowledge, like "the more you do it, the better you get" or "start simple and work your way up" or "remember to take breaks". In short, teachers are like grocery stores. Sure, you could go farm-to-farm trying to get what you need, but it's much easier to go to one source that is experienced in getting you what you need. Rebuttal?
037756.answer: in my experience, the teacher student connection has never been strong enough for any of the good/important stuff to make the transfer. this is reconfirmed again and again every time i hear someone say "i used to do music, i took lessons and i hated it and quit." added to all the great players out there who are self taught. advice can surely be transfered from one person to another, but it seems it mostly works on a non-teacher basis, not scheduled. for example you find a player you really really like and you check out all their stuff. or maybe there is someone you trust and you can ask them questions about certain things. i don't know if that counts as teaching but that works really well and i try to make that happen on the questions page as much as possible. although sometimes, my best answer is not something they are ready to hear at the time, or maybe they just aren't interested in doing the same way as me, which is ok, but it would get very awkward if someone was paying for us to have required meetings each week and pretend we were getting somewhere

037819.question: people are having trouble with the audio when they listen with vs without headphones?? I've never had that problem when I listen to your music. I can hear all of the audio just fine.
037819.answer: if you listen to it through a phone speaker, tablet speaker, or laptop speaker, you can't hear any of the bass, or any of the low frequencies whatsoever. it's just not there. it's physically impossible on a speaker of that size. any normal sized speaker would be just fine, but on a speaker less than 1cm, mostly what you hear is a lot of S and T, and the hi-hat, and maybe a little more if you listen close, but zero bass. which is why i think i would like to start the recording of my next song without any bass frequencies, just to make sure i get the thing so that i think it's strong enough even with zero bass. Then, go in and add bass as needed, for bass-capable systems. but first make sure it completely stands strong with no bass. we all know it's possible, like i said, they made music for game boy and it was damn good. and when i say gameboy i mean also millions of phone apps, and ringtones, that have been popular since then. but if you design the whole song on a system where you can hear the bass, you're taking a risk, because you never know if the song is still gonna be strong enough if you delete the entire bass. i've taken that risk for my entire career because i'm mostly too scared to think about it. but i think it's a good time to try to take care of it because phone/tablet speakers aren't going to get any larger, and there is no technological breakthrough any time soon that will allow bass to exist at that size. but don't worry, i will go into bass mode and additively put the bass where it needs be, after i get it so it is solid basslessly

037831.question: I need a bit of help. Every time I try starting a new project, I think it's going to be great and wonderful. I do in fact start it, however I just stop in the middle of making it and never finish it. Sometimes I even think of a new project that I want to make and completely scrap the old one. Then I get stuck in a loop of half-doing projects. A third of my computer are now WIP projects that I'm never going to finish. It's quite horrible, but I never really delete them because I think to myself "I'll do it once. I'll finish all of them". I never do, and I just continue filling my computer with half-done projects. Is there a way for me to stop doing this? I haven't finished a single project for many months, even though I want to do it.
037831.answer: do data backups and make sure they are all saved. there is very little that is stopping you from developing the skill of rescuing. you could start by getting a text file and making a chronological list of all of them, with brief notes on what you think they need for the next step. be open to the possibility of item cancellation at this stage, but expect most of them to not be cancelled
