037966.question: Bill, i've been playing the piano for months, i listen to the songs i enjoy and i learn to play them by ear. I'm good at finding out the melody or the lead vocal's notes, but i'm having troubles identifying the chords and extra stuff other than the melody. what do you suggest me to do? i started to become familiar with the sounds of some of the chords i use a lot (A,Am, Em, F , Fm, Bb, C D G etc.) . Do i just listen and play more?
037966.answer: a good starting trick is to pause the music and then unpause-pause very quickly. this might not work on a streaming site like youtube, but it will would very well on an offline player. when i was a kid i used to do it with a CD player. if you just listen to that micro-second of the song, you can pick out 1 note at a time. write down all the chords to a song (in time, with bar lines, etc.)..... once you do this for about 30 or 40 songs, i think you will find that you don't have to search for the individual notes anymore. ... maybe not even pause it at all. After about 100 more songs, you probably won't even have to listen to the song, you will be able to do it from memory. after about 1000 songs, you will probably be able to hear someone singing the melody for a song you have never heard before, without hearing the chords, and figure out what the chords should be. after 10,000 songs, you should be able to play along with them on the first try, never having heard the song before, and have them think you already knew the song

038004.question: So, say you have a note that goes til the end of a beat, and then a note right at the top of the next beat (like a quarter note on beat 1, then a quarter note on beat 2).. Wouldn't that mean that, technically, that first note shouldn't be released until the exact same moment that the 2nd note is played? If you have to lift up from the 1st note to play the 2nd note, then wouldn't you be cutting the duration of the the quarter note slightly short just for that little tiny moment between the notes? Is that little moment so negligible that I shouldn't even think about that? And then, the natural sustain of the instrument/sound could effect that as well? Like sometimes it would be impossible to sustain the first note until the exact moment the 2nd note is played (like if you're playing 2 fretted notes on the same string of a guitar or bass that are farther apart than what you can reach without moving your hand)... If I want to have 2 instruments play the same line, would it be more accurate to think of that 1st quarter note as, like a dotted eighth note and a sixteenth rest (or maybe even an eighth note, dotted sixteenth and a 32nd rest) so that the release of the notes happen at the exact same time? I've never really thought about this before, but now that I am thinking about it, I'm confusing myself. When I read rhythmic notation I'm usually thinking primarily about where the notes hit, more so than the duration of each note. Like if I had 4 quarter notes, I'd now that each note should be played on the beat, but I'd probably play the 4 quarter notes no different than then if it were written as alternating dotted eighth notes and sixteenth rests (unless it's a really slow tempo) Obviously for something like a quarter note and a quarter rest, I wouldn't play the same way as a half note.. but when you get down to those little itty bitty tiny moments in between the notes, do those essentially not matter rhythmically?
038004.answer: if no articulation is written, i think it might be assumed that there is at least a little bit of space before the next note

038028.question: I've taken theory III and I still don't understand tritone substitution can you explain it to me
038028.answer: imagine you are in a song, minding your own business, ... let's say the song is in the key of C ... and let's say there is a G7 chord. .. following me so far? the G7 chord has notes b and f in the mid-range, that's the important notes of the chord. (that's a tritone interval but that's not why it's called substitution, we haven't done the substitution yet, that will be in the bass.) so let's say you play b and f notes (at the same time) in the middle range, and the bass plays G (note.) that pretty much makes a G7 chord. ok now the bass player plays a prank and plays Db (note) instead, while the piano still plays the b+f notes. pow, now it's a Db7 chord

038042.question: what is your process for doing a vocal key test
038042.answer: sing various parts of the song at the proper volume, especially the highest and lowest parts. see if it sounds good, feels good, and is comfortable to sing and hear, in that key. if it's too low, try a half step higher. if it's too high try a half step lower. if it seems ok, test a half step above and below and see if it's any better there

038074.question: 6.29.18 2:38 pm how do you know which one best represents the music at hand if you've listened to the song in all the keys and it sounds great in all of them? do different keys convey different tones or different emotions? how can this be explained since there's no objective definition of a pitch the way there is of a meter or a kilogram?
038074.answer: which ever key the song is in, that's the key signature to use. if the music sort of is switchy between key centers, you'll have to pick one which causes the least amount of problems it's mainly the pitch and range that changes. the main place this matters is usually for the vocal it's faster and slower frequencies, but as they get higher, some things might double or cut in half (go up or down an octave) so it's ultimately a circle

038078.question: 6.30.18 1:12am I wrote a song that could either be considered to be in 3/4, with a tempo of 162, or in 4/4, with a tempo of 54 (so each "3/4" measure would equal one beat if it was in 4/4). Is there a right or wrong way to interpret this? One time you talked about a "reasonability zone" of tempos between 60 and 120 bpm and neither of these tempos is in that zone so I think this is sort of An exception to that rule. Thoughts?
038078.answer: no, but for a compromise you might want to try 6/8 if you put it in 6/8, the size of the bars will be within that reasonability zone (between 2 and 4 seconds per bar). you can also do it either of the 2 ways you tried it, if you don't mind the bars going by really fast or really slow

038577.question: i have a sweet hook that i've fleshed out to a whole chorus-y section, but every time i try to write the rest of the song i just come up with more hooks and other lines that belong in different songs. have you encountered this and if so do u have any strategies
038577.answer: yes this might take patience. it is like a doctor's diagnosis, you are the doctor. and you need to figure out how to take care of this piece. this task can be confusing and requires patience, but it can be done. it's usually just a long game of "what do we know" and asking many questions and eventually you will figure out what the solution is. if you test things categorically you can eliminate things instantly and narrow it down pretty swiftly. there are many questions you could ask, but i will try to list some of the questions that i usually ask. 1. does it seem to want to stay in the same form (same chords, same form, etc. same thing) for the 'other section.' some songs absolutely need that, and some songs are absolutely allergic to it. just doing a simple test and listen to whether it makes you extremely happy or uncomfortable, should be pretty easy to answer that one. another thing you might look at is lyrical content. another important tip, i heard a rumor that dave grohl gave this advice once, and the advice is called "get to the chorus"... like don't waste any freakin time if you don't have to. here's an interesting thing to check for: could you actually start with the chorus. in some cases this is just right, in some cases it's all wrong. a simple test should prove that one way or the other. here's a neat trick, do a regular run-thru of the chorus and figure out what wants to go Next. if that works then you could get your 'other section' from there. then you would be on to a different question which is which goes first and how. another strategy which is similar to one of the ones i already said, remember that the point of this whole thing is the part that you know already. the part that exists (the chorus, in this case). so just focus on that. that's the point of this whole thing. so maybe even start bargaining for that to be really the only part of the song in the entire song. and then just see how wrong that is and make adjustments from there. here's another thing to check for, starting with the chorus and then do another chorus with different lyrics, etc. i'm sure you've heard a million songs that are like that. that's often just the ticket if you have a strong chorus that seems to be the star of the show. those are just some things to check for, over all this is going to be a puzzle but if you are gentle with it the answer will arrive. if the part you already wrote is great then it is guaranteed that there is a solution. also i almost forgot to mention, if you come up with extraneous things that are good but don't fit, always log those (separately)

Hip hop and rap and pop aren't music... etc etc etc" And this guy's so happy that he met someone (me) who he can "nerd out" with and gush about all of his favorite music and stuff.... But, how can I tell this guy that just because I like some of that "classic rock" stuff, doesn't mean that I don't also like the music I hear on the radio today, and (even though I don't like genres) most of the music in listen to probably wouldn't be called "rock" by most people. I feel I've reached the point of no return and it's too late for me to admit that I like a lot of the music he loves hating on. 039086.question: you mentioned a couple times that you have made decisions about what to do next based on some kind of "tournament" format. do you have any tips for how to do this effectively or things you've learned from doing it. like, what rules do you make the decisions follow, what will get them disqualified for cheating and so forth. I might be doing this soon
039086.answer: what i've developed is a hybrid system between sheer number randomization and actually choosing. actually choosing can be impossible, especially if you are terrified of picking the wrong one. sheer randomization works on the idea that there could not possibly be any right or wrong one and it doesn't matter. the hybrid system goes like this: make preliminary exclusions for various reasons, and then randomize amongst the finalists. Start by listing all the items. go through them all, and it is very important that you fully and truly check out every one, go find the source material, find your notes, find the demos, whatever you have, but don't just go based on the title or memory. at least half the time the song turns out better than you remember it, if you actually go and listen to it. then start excluding ones you absolutely know should not be picked, and it should be only for very specific reasons. usually these reasons would be in direct relation to the most recent song(s) i released. for example, last year i released a song called california, then a song called i love you. when choosing for the next song, a song called "california love" might be a bad choice. other common exclusion reasons are if the tempo or groove is too similar to the previous song. So i go through the entire list and make exclusions. which should be minimal but recently i've become extremely particular and exclude almost everything, which is getting back to the original problem with manual 'conscious' picking (and the problem is "being a chicken"). i would be discouraged by this, but, the good news is, every time there are at least a few songs that absolutely jump out at me and scream yes. so i guess this is ok but one thing that complicates this system is that more complete (written) songs tend to be more obvious choices. where as songs which only have 1 line written tend to not be as strong a contender as perhaps they should be. especially because i would get to write the majority of it brand new if it were picked, likely enabling it to be an even stronger pick. randomization boosts those small bits' chances of being picked, but doing pre-elimination often wipes out many of those. this also brings up an interesting point about doing this ONLY with finished (written) songs, vs including all fragments. in the past 2 years i've done it where i include all fragments, because the fragments are usually newer, and stronger, (newer because they would be less likely to have been finished yet, and stronger because they are newer, and even stronger because i get to finish them in the present time). but the drawback for including bits is like i said they often have trouble competing with more complete ones. so for this reason it is important to be extra specific in your exclusion reasons, vividly explaining to yourself the reason. (too similar to last song, etc.). and "too unwritten yet" is not a valid excuse, and that's almost a great reason to keep it. this is why randomization helps, because it will boost the chances for those bits which were too small to demand being picked, but yet not excludable for any specific reason. which essentially allows you to write a mostly entirely new song, and make it good on demand, because it's already been selected as the next one to record. so once you have it down to finalists, sometimes i go through again because i am usually so darn scared to pick the wrong one, probably because to fully produce a song and an entire video by yourself with rising standards takes a very long time so i am very scared to be stuck with the wrong one. so sometimes i go through the list and comb it down again, but it's probably bad to do that too much because you end up wiping out all the tiny fragments. finally when you have maybe 20-40 finalists, then just a simple random number selection (from random.org, for example) will pick for you, and if you did your exclusions properly you will hopefully never run into a wrong pick ('really?? another marijuana song?')

039739.question: 1) https://billwurtz.com/journal201108312213.html 4) https://billwurtz.com/reality/201205120046.mp4 I think I figured out where I went wrong. I thought one of the main story arcs in your personal narrative is gathering the courage to murder this cowardly version of yourself so that you can finally be free to explore and explode the universe the way you're meant to. But I guess he wasn't dead, because when I arrived at your door holding a new set of mysterious keys, that guy opened the door just long enough to slam it back in my face and yell at me for disturbing your slumber. Talk about frustrating, sad, and not very nice. 3) https://billwurtz.com/reality/201201081536.mp4 But I'll still raise a toast to the version of you that might still be alive somewhere... the version of you that might still have it in him to burn that stubborn little bitch's clothes off once and for all. There's a lot of new doors for you to open and a lot of new rooms for you to explore in this life and I'd hate for you to delay your journey any longer than you already have. (Yeah, it's not always gonna be smooth sailing and perhaps the boat has seen better days, but as far as magic goes, you ain't seen nothin' yet.) Or don't. Cower in the corner playing the same level of solitaire over and over and over. Your choice.
039739.answer: so far i'm doing great, although everyone feels afraid from time to time everyone has doubts sometimes. it's a part of everyone i'm not sure what you mean but i know who this is because you've been sending me a long string of messages for several months now with a deep obsession with my past (which is ok) but from the start you had a deep certainty that you were somehow my soul mate and that i was meant to be with you. you probably sent me at least 500 messages like this before i even responded to any of them. and when i finally told you to please leave me alone, the messages continued but mostly took a more negative turn. many of the messages have been sexual in nature, and most of them make no secret of spending countless hours deeply analyzing everything i have ever done, which is fine, but the nature of the messages is more than several steps over the line into the stalker creepy zone. i wish i could properly explain this for people who have not seen the types of messages you have sent me. obsessing over people is great and fine, i'm not saying obsession is bad, i used to act out mr. roger's opening routine verbatim hundreds of times a day. i don't want anyone to misunderstand what i'm saying here. obsession is fine, but what you have done beyond that is send me a never ending stream of messages presuming that you are destined to be with me in every way including romantically. it would be difficult for anyone reading this to understand the nature of this because they have not seen the messages. but i was uncomfortable after about the 50th message, ever since you started sending me loads of messages every day insisting you are my soul mate, looking forward to having sex with me, that sort of thing. all before you ever got a response from me. sure i believe in soul mates, sure i believe in supernatural stuff, sure i believe in the magic of this universe, but you're stalking me and it's turned into harassment. i don't like it and i never liked it, i've tried to tell you to stop, i don't think you're going to, that's ok, i still don't like it, but i don't think i can count on you stopping, i am wondering if you will stop, but i just need to let you know that you are really being a creep here and you have been for a long time, and i wish you would stop trying to blame me for not being 'open to the world' when really it's simply that i am not open to being .. . .. for lack of a more eloquent term .. ... .... stalked and creeped upon. that's all i have to say and i don't like having to post this publicly and i realize most people reading this have not seen all the messages you've sent me so they couldn't possibly know the extent and sheer magnitude and nature of the messages you have sent me but i just need to express this here because you seem to have no intention of ever stopping
